tossups.question: So-called "cones" named for this process are generated by escape from LyC ("lie-c") sources, such as Seyfert galaxies. The Planck mission measured the Thomson optical depth to date a large-scale phase transition caused by this process, which was originally dated to around z = 6 based on detection of the Gunn-Peterson trough. The (emphasize) reverse of this process occurred at the surface of last scattering via photon decoupling, thus producing the (*) cosmic microwave background. This process's energy equals (read slowly) "proton number, times elementary charge squared, divided by radius". Recombination is the reverse of this process, whose required energy is 13.6 electronvolts for hydrogen. The electron binding energy is the energy needed to induce, for 10 points, what process of separating an electron from its atom?
tossups.answer: ionization [or ionizing; accept ionization cones or epoch of reionization or ionization energy; prompt on decoupling]

tossups.question: In 1752, production of this commodity in the Joseon ("joh-sun") dynasty was consolidated to facilities at Bunwon-ri ("boon-wun-ree"). Prisoners who were captured during Toyotomi Hideyoshi's invasion of Korea started production of this good in Satsuma ("saht-soo-mah"), which was known for its infamously low quality. Varieties of this good included Swatow and kraak, the latter of which was named for being carried in carracks; both were largely purchased using the excess supply of (*) silver from the Americas. The mineral petuntse ("peh-TOON-tsuh"), or bai dunzi ("bye doon-dzuh"), was critical in the manufacture of this good in the city of Jingdezhen ("jing-duh-zhen"). Since Europeans had difficulty manufacturing this good itself, craftsmen in Delft created "imitation wares". For 10 points, European merchants often visited the Ming dynasty to buy what valuable glazed ceramics?
tossups.answer: porcelain [accept china; prompt on ceramics before mentioned; prompt on wares before mentioned; prompt on pottery]

tossups.question: On the fourth day of a festival in this city, priests recited a creation myth after sighting the constellation Pegasus. During that festival, boats brought statues of gods to this city to help its tutelary deity achieve victory in a local version of the Chaoskampf ("KAH-ohs-kampf") story. This city's Uras gate was a focal point of its Akitu ("AH-kee-too") festival, which honored the consort of Sarpanit and featured a symbolic procession led by the god (*) Nabu. In a tale that begins with the line "when on high", this city's chief god - the son of Nudimmud, or Ea - obtains his rightful place as ruler by seizing the Tablets of Destiny after slaying the water serpent goddess Tiamat. For 10 points, Marduk was the patron god of what Mesopotamian city, whose ziggurat may have inspired a Biblical tower?
tossups.answer: Babylon [or Kadiĝira; or Babilim; or Babel]

tossups.question: In a 2003 novel, this character recalls selling cigarettes to pay for an operation on her grandmother's nose. This character serves tea to six old women who discuss the title euphemism for vaginal surgery in that novel, Embroideries. In another work, this character parodies Michelangelo's Pieta by drawing Mary holding a dead soldier to gain admission to art school. In that work, she reads the Marxist comic "Dialectical Materialism" and is mentored by her (*) uncle Anoosh. This author returns to her home country and sees her friend Nami fall off a building, after a wine-drinking party is shut down by religious police, in a work which depicts her move to Vienna at age 14. For 10 points, what author wrote about coming of age during the 1979 Islamic Revolution in her graphic novel Persepolis?
tossups.answer: Marjane Satrapi [accept either underlined portion; accept Marji Satrapi]

tossups.question: With Tom Glazer and Bess and Baldwin Hawes, this musician recorded Spanish Civil War songs on the album Songs of the Lincoln Battalion. This musician (emphasize) wrote a song which declares "a time for peace, I swear it's not too late," consisting of eight verses from the Book of Ecclesiastes. This musician repeated the line "the big fool said to push on" in a song about a platoon wading in a river in Louisiana that was censored from The (*) Smothers Brothers Comedy. This singer wrote "Turn! Turn! Turn!" and "Waist Deep in the Big Muddy" and co-wrote "If I Had a Hammer" with Lee Hays, a member of The Weavers. Verses like "We'll walk hand in hand" were added by this musician to a song he popularized, titled "We Shall Overcome". For 10 points, name this folk musician and social activist.
tossups.answer: Pete Seeger [or Peter Seeger]

tossups.question: This book illustrates a key idea with the story of the elderly African-American John Lambert, who was donated a kidney by white accountant Andy Boschma. This book's findings inspired its author, a professor at Harvard's Kennedy School, to conduct the Saguaro Seminar there. This book suggests that, since U.S. geographic mobility has declined over time, its central finding is only partially explained by the "re-potting hypothesis". It argues that the rise of "tertiary" (*) associations, such as the Sierra Club, in favor of "secondary" ones where people directly know each other, reflects a "decline in civic engagement" allegorized by lower membership in leagues for the title activity. For 10 points, name this book about social capital by Robert Putnam, whose title activity is done in alleys.
tossups.answer: Bowling Alone

tossups.question: This poem's narrator dreams of being "raptured" like Achilles being taken to Scyros or Ganymede being snatched by a gold-plumed eagle. This poem ends by telling the reader it wishes to speak more of the "sweet draught that ne'er would satiate me," before holy water leaves the speaker "Pure and disposed to mount unto the stars". Its narrator spends a night in a valley with such princes as Ottokar, Rudolph, and Henry of England after meeting the troubadour (*) Sordello, who explains a rule that progress is only possible while the sun is shining. This poem is set on a continent in the Southern Hemisphere inhabited by shades, where the Garden of Eden can be reached by climbing a seven-terraced mountain. Dante travels the place where souls repent in, for 10 points, what second poem of the Divine Comedy?
tossups.answer: Purgatorio [or Purgatory; prompt on The Divine Comedy or Divinia Commedia]

tossups.question: Tourists of this territory often visit a sharp black limestone formation surrounded by verdant landscape, known as "Hell". Local legend claims that this territory's best-known feature originated after villagers near Gun Bay rescued a son of George III during the Wreck of the Ten Sail. Because this archipelago's laws (emphasize) introduced a concept called an SPC, it is often the ultimate destination of the "Double Irish with a Dutch Sandwich" strategy, much like Jersey and (*) Bermuda. Like Guyana, the capital of this British overseas territory is called George Town, which is found on the "Grand" one of its three constituent islands. A type of crocodilian lends its name to, for 10 points, what Caribbean archipelago, which is home to many shell corporations due to its reputation as a tax haven?
tossups.answer: Cayman Islands [or Caymans; accept Grand Cayman]

tossups.question: One property relevant to these substances can be calculated by the POPS algorithm and is reported in a "fractional" form by the tool VADAR. That property relevant to these substances is classically calculated with the "rolling ball" algorithm developed by Shrake and Rupley. These substances are viewed as continuous dielectrics that interact with an (*) "accessible surface area" in "implicit" models. Whether the SN1 or SN2 mechanism is preferred depends on whether these substances act as hydrogen bond donors, which classifies them as "protic" or "aprotic". Acetone's ability to be one of these substances makes it useful for cleaning laboratory glassware. For 10 points, name these liquid substances, whose "universal" example is water.
tossups.answer: solvents

tossups.question: Samuel D. Greene's The Broken Seal endorsed this cause and includes the testimony of David Miller, the publisher of the Republican Advocate. Thurlow Weed founded the Rochester Enquirer to support this cause. This cause gained traction after the purported dead body of William Morgan washed up on the shores of Lake Ontario. At the first-ever presidential nominating convention, William (*) Wirt was picked as the candidate for a party that supported this cause; that party only won Vermont in the election of 1832. Conspiracy theorists who support this cause argue that the presence of the "eye of providence" on the one dollar bill is proof that a certain organization was key in founding the United States. For 10 points, what sentiment involved opposing a secret society formed by bricklayers?
tossups.answer: anti-Masonic [accept descriptions involving opposing the Masons or Freemason conspiracies]

tossups.question: This author dismisses pronoun confusion as a "silly mistake of gender" and opens by asserting "I am a man" in the essay "Introducing Myself". The protagonist of a novel by this author uses "mindspeak" to communicate with a class of prophets called Foretellers. That protagonist created by this author travels on a "nearly fast-as-light" ship to a world whose natives undergo a fertile period called kemmer, during which they cease being (*) genderless and adopt sexual characteristics. An essay by William James inspired this author's story about a city whose perfection depends on the "abominable misery" of a single child. This author of "Omelas" created the Terran Genly Ai, who researches the Gethenians, in her novel Left Hand of Darkness. The young wizard Ged appears in the Earthsea novels written by, for 10 points, what sci-fi author?
tossups.answer: Ursula K. LeGuin

tossups.question: Parts of Gabriel Fauré's Impromptu No. 6 for this instrument have been attributed to Alphonse Hasselmans. A contemporary French performer of this instrument, Isabelle Moretti, has recorded many solo pieces for it by Marcel Tournier ("toor-NYAY"). Claude Debussy's Danse sacrée et Danse profane ("dons sah-KRAY eh dons pro-FAN") is a work for orchestra and this solo instrument; Debussy also wrote a sonata for this instrument, flute, and viola. This instrument plays the same (*) D twelve times, depicting the "stroke of midnight," to open Camille Saint-Saëns' ("kuh-MEE sahn-SOHN'Z") Danse macabre ("dons muh-KAHB"). A glissando on this instrument follows the flute solo in the opening of Prelude to the Afternoon of a Faun. The violinist in Rimsky-Korsakov's Scheherezade is accompanied by arpeggios on, for 10 points, what pedaled instrument with 47 strings which are plucked by hand?
tossups.answer: harp [accept concert harp or pedal harp]

tossups.question: An infrastructure project connecting two members of this group of polities titles a book by historian Sean McMeekin, which explores this group's efforts to instigate a jihad by funding Ahmed Sharif. A scandal broke when a member of this group was found to be negotiating separately with Prince Sixtus of Bourbon-Parma. A so-called "second national catastrophe" resulted from one member of this group signing the Treaty of Neuilly-sur-Seine ("noo-YEE-soor-sen"). The creation of this (*) coalition renewed interest in the Baghdad railway, originally envisioned as part of the weltpolitik ("VELT-poh-lee-teek") of one its members. Bulgaria joined this coalition a year after its formation, which happened after one of its members sent a "blank check" after the Black Hand killed Franz Ferdinand. For 10 points, what coalition opposed the Allied Powers in World War I?
tossups.answer: Central Powers [or Central Empires; accept Quadruple Alliance; prompt on Triple Alliance by asking for a more general group; do not accept or prompt on "Great Powers"]

tossups.question: These places are rated across six domains, including timeliness, effectiveness, and equity, in metrics published by AHRQ. A staffing company which mainly provides services to these places, Envision, was acquired for $9.9 billion by KKR in 2018, in one of the largest-ever private equity deals. Besides Vanderbilt and Nissan, Nashville's largest employer is a corporation named for these places founded by the Frist family and formerly led by Florida senator (*) Rick Scott. Improving the performance of these facilities is the main goal of CMS's Readmissions Reduction Program. Examples of them include Cedars-Sinai near Los Angeles, Memorial Sloan Kettering in New York, and Mass General in Boston. For 10 points, name these facilities which provide inpatient care, staffed by doctors and nurses.
tossups.answer: hospitals [accept Hospital Corporation of America; accept medical center or cancer center; prompt on clinics; prompt on health care facilities]

tossups.question: During this event, a character relates how Alexander had "intoxicates in his prains" when he killed "his best friend Cleitus," explaining his objection to an order to "Kill the poys and the luggage!" In a prologue, the chorus asks if the "casques / that did affright the air" at this event can be crammed into "this wooden O" after invoking a "Muse of fire". During this event, the phrase "O Seigneur Dieu!" ("sen-yeur DYEU") is misinterpreted as the name of a gentleman by Pistol. The cousins (*) York and Suffolk die in each other's arms during this event, as related by Exeter. It begins after a speech rebuking Westmoreland's wish for "more men," in which a king calls his army "we few, we happy few, we band of brothers". A Shakespeare play depicts, for 10 points, what battle won on St. Crispin's day by Henry V?
tossups.answer: Battle of Agincourt [prompt on Act IV of Henry V before "Henry"; prompt on St. Crispin's Day before "Crispin's"; prompt on invasion of France or Hundred Years War]

tossups.question: Marcel Breuer's Model B3 Chair was renamed by the Gavina Group after this artist. This artist mixed paint with sand for paintings such as Accompanied Contrast. This artist's painting Small Dream in Red was the only color plate included in a treatise on geometric composition which this artist wrote while teaching at the Bauhaus. This artist used the metaphor of a "whole (*) triangle moving slowly, almost invisibly forwards and upwards" in his treatise Concerning the Spiritual in Art. Purple, black, and red concentric rings appear in the corner of this artist's Composition VIII. Franz Marc was a member of a group that this artist founded in Munich. For 10 points, name this Russian artist whose The Blue Rider inspired an Expressionist art group with the same name.
tossups.answer: Wassily Wassilyevich Kandinsky

tossups.question: One of these things named BLAKE2 is based on the HAIFA construction. One type of these things named for Alfred Zobrist is used in chess computers to implement transposition tables. When these things change significantly in response to very small input changes, they may obey the strict avalanche criterion. One type of these things is used to match patterns between strings in the (*) Rabin-Karp algorithm. The output of these things is modified by linear or quadratic probing. If keys are known in advance and the set is static, these functions do not map multiple inputs to the same output, thus avoiding "collisions." For 10 points, name these functions that map arbitrary sized data to fixed values, which are then stored and indexed in a namesake table.
tossups.answer: hash functions [accept hashes or hash tables; accept rolling hash functions]

tossups.question: The first Biblical occurrence of the number 666 is connected to an order by this figure. The Beast of the Earth carries Moses's rod and an object owned by this figure. In an Islamic account, this figure listens to a group of ants and is angered by the hoopoe's absence until it tells him that it saw Bilqis worshiping the sun. A section called the Ars Goetia begins a grimoire named for this figure, who invokes Asmodeus to aid one of his projects. The (*) "Lesser Key" of this figure lists a number of ways to summon demons; this figure himself controls demons with his hexagram-inscribed ring, which he uses to help create a building to replace the tabernacle. He's visited by, and in some traditions converts, the queen of the Arabian land of Sheba. For 10 points, name this builder of the First Temple, a famously wise Israelite king.
tossups.answer: Solomon [or Shlomoh; or Sulayman; accept Jedidiah; accept Seal of Solomon; accept Lesser Key of Solomon; accept Solomon's Temple or Temple of Solomon]

tossups.question: Peter Marra found that the lack of low-frequency acoustic niches in these ecosystems raises the pitch of bird calls. Birds in these ecosystems can be classified as "exploiters," "adapters," or "avoiders". These ecosystems are classified as group 11 ("one-one") in a paper by Ellis and Ramankutty describing new biomes. These ecosystems have a near-total lack of specialist species; instead they have omnivorous generalist ecotypes with improved (*) problem-solving ability. These ecosystems are warmed by a namesake "heat island" effect. Since the creation of these ecosystems can cause habitat fragmentation, some of these ecosystems contain so-called "open spaces" or "green spaces" for wildlife. For 10 points, name these ecosystems in which raccoons scavenge garbage and pigeons nest on buildings.
tossups.answer: urban ecosystems [or cities or towns; accept suburb or suburban ecosystems; accept anything that indicates environments with dense human habitation; do not accept or prompt on environments with low-densities of human habitation like "rural" or "villages"]

tossups.question: Under this leader, Hastings Park was converted into a temporary center for workers who would be later relocated to work on sugar beet farms. This leader's party was marred by a scandal involving bribes paid by Beauharnois Light, Heat, and Power. After Igor Gouzenko defected to this leader’s country, he ordered an investigation into Soviet espionage. Following an incident in which he faced censure from H. H. Stevens, Arthur Meighen succeeded this (*) prime minister. In that incident, he ordered Lord Byng to dissolve parliament. Many Japanese immigrants were interned in Slocan Valley on the orders of this prime minister, who encouraged his country's troops to assist the RAF in the Dieppe Raid. For 10 points, give this longest-serving Canadian prime minister, who led Canada during World War II.
tossups.answer: William Lyon Mackenzie King

bonuses.leadin: In September 2020, these two countries signed an economic deal in what was widely viewed as a foreign policy victory for the Trump administration. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Kosovo AND Serbia [accept Republic of Kosovo or Republika e Kosovës for "Kosovo"; accept Republic of Serbia or Republika Srbija for "Serbia"]
Republic of North Macedonia [or Republika Severna Makedonija, or Republika e Maqedonisë së Veriut]
parts: Name these two countries led by Aleksandar Vučić ("VOO-chich") and Avdullah Hoti, respectively.
With their deal, Kosovo and Serbia sought to join a "Mini" version of this economic and political area of Europe, governed by a namesake treaty which abolishes passport and border controls within it.

This country, like Kosovo and Serbia, made joining the "Mini Schengen Zone" a key goal of economic development. This country added "North" to its name as part of a compromise with its neighbor Greece.

bonuses.leadin: The "Humble Petition and Advice" allowed holders of this title to appoint their own successor. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Lord Protector of the Commonwealth of England, Scotland and Ireland
parts: Give this executive title, whose holders were expected to consult with a Council of State of up to 21 members. The first holder of this title commanded the New Model Army along with Thomas Fairfax.
Oliver Cromwell took the title "Lord Protector" after his victory in this conflict, which resulted in the execution of the Stuart king Charles I.
This document, authored by John Lambert, officially invested Cromwell with the title of "Lord Protector". It also prevented Catholics and known Royalists from voting and worshipping freely.

bonuses.leadin: The increasing alcoholism of this writer's later years is reflected in the theme of his poem "Here's, a bottle and an honest friend!" For 10 points each:
parts: Name this writer whose poems, such as "To a Mouse," are written in the Scots language.
In this Robert Burns poem, the title farmer ignores his wife's advice to not get drunk on Sunday, after which he sees a vision of "warlocks and witches in a dance".

The narrator of "Tam O'Shanter" calls this allegorical figure "inspiring" and says of him, "What dangers thou canst make us scorn!" Burns's "ballad" of this figure describes "three kings into the east" who swore this figure "should die".

bonuses.leadin: You can tell a lot about a person from the color of their urine. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: myoglobin [do not accept or prompt on "hemoglobin"]
phenylalanine AND tyrosine [accept Phe or F for phenylalanine; accept Tyr or Y for tyrosine; prompt on partial answer]
parts: Tea-colored urine may indicate this protein, which is released by skeletal muscle destruction and has a hyperbolic oxygen dissociation curve.
Urine that darkens under sunlight may indicate a group of diseases named for these compounds, which contain 4 pyrrole rings. One of them binds to iron in heme.

Urine that blackens when exposed to air may indicate alkaptonuria, a disease caused by inability to break down metabolites of these two amino acids. Along with tryptophan, these two amino acids allow quantification of protein concentration in the A280 method.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about pioneering costume designer Ruth Carter:
answers_sanitized: Do The Right Thing (by Spike Lee)
parts: Carter borrowed from one of these artworks to design a gold-studded costume for What's Love Got to Do with It. David Fincher directed one of these works for Madonna's song "Vogue".
Carter asked local artist NaSha to paint a misspelled t-shirt reading "Bed-Stuy" for this film, for which she also designed Radio Raheem's iconic knuckle rings.

Carter unusually used this technique to design many of the costumes for Black Panther. The set of Gilles-Alexandre Deschaud's ("zheel-ah-lek-SOND deh-SHOW'Z") award-winning short film Chase Me was created entirely using this technique.

bonuses.leadin: This force deflects gunshots to the right in the Northern hemisphere, and to the left in the Southern hemisphere. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: omega cross omega cross r [It's technically omega cross (omega cross r), since the cross product isn't associative; omega cross omega is zero.]
parts: Name this fictitious force that appears along with the centrifugal and Euler forces when an object moves in a rotating reference frame.
When applied to the Earth, the strength of the Coriolis force is proportional to this function of the latitude.

The centrifugal force in a rotating reference frame equals negative mass times this function of the angular velocity vector, omega, and the radial position vector, r. Give an answer in terms of omega and r that uses at least one vector operation, and assume parentheses are implied.

bonuses.leadin: An alternate name for the city of Puri references the similarity of the arrangement of its holy sites to one of these sacred objects. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: conch shell [or sacred conch; or divine conch; or shankha; or chank; accept vamavarta shankha or dakshinavarti shankha; accept Shankha Kshetra; prompt on seashell or snail shell]
om [or onkara; accept pranava, akshara, or ekashara]
milk [or kshira; or khir; or shir; or dugdha; or dudh]
parts: Name this instrument played in Hindu rituals. Vishnu holds one named Panchajanya ("pawn-chuh-JUN-yuh") in his upper-left hand, representing his control of sound and the universe's interconnectedness.
The conch's sound represents this sacred syllable, which embodies Atman and Brahman and so is commonly used in Hindu prayers.

Images of Vishnu are often bathed by pouring water or this liquid from a conch. The conch is one of the fourteen ratnas ("RUT-nuh'z") or treasures made from a large body of this liquid, which is also poured over lingas.

bonuses.leadin: In a story by this author, a mother states, "try to walk like a lady and not like the slut you are so bent on becoming". For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Jamaica Kincaid [or Elaine Cynthia Potter Richardson]
At the Bottom of the River
parts: Name this author who wrote about a young woman growing up in the West Indies in her story "Girl". She wrote about a girl who becomes an au pair in her novel Lucy.
Kincaid included her story "Girl" in this collection, whose other stories include "In the Night". In its title story, a girl names objects like a flute made of wood in order to embrace her identity.
"In the Night" and "Girl" were published in this Manhattan-based magazine which also published James Thurber's "The Secret Life of Walter Mitty".

bonuses.leadin: Artifacts from this culture, such as the Trundholm sun chariot, are similar to those of the Sintashta culture near the Caspian Sea, suggesting persistence of Indo-European motifs among early Germanic peoples. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Nordic Bronze Age [prompt on Bronze Age]
parts: Name this archaeological culture whose sites - such as the King's Grave - contain imported Mycenaean weapons, evidencing its extensive trade with the rest of Europe.
The most valued export of the Nordic Bronze Age was this brownish fossilized tree resin, prized for its use in jewelry.

Nordic Bronze Age sun worshippers created many of these works depicting their rituals. Derived from the Greek for "rock carving," this term denotes pictures made by removing a rock's surface, as done by the Anasazi.

bonuses.leadin: An artist created a series of paintings of this place after creating a similar series of the Rue St. Lazare ("sahnt luh-zahr"). For 10 points each:
parts: Camille Pissarro created a series of 14 paintings depicting what Parisian street at various times of day and in different weather conditions? One of those paintings depicts a Mardi Gras parade on this street.
This contemporary of Pissarro used Nadar's apartment to paint the Boulevard des Capucines. This artist's painting Impression, Sunrise helped coin the name of the Impressionist movement.
A Pissarro painting depicts steam ships leaving this city's harbor on an "overcast day". Monet painted a series depicting this city's cathedral at various times of day.

bonuses.leadin: Anacaona, a cacique of these people, was known for composing several areytos. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: smallpox [accept Variola major or Variola minor]
parts: Name these indigenous people of the Caribbean who interacted with Christopher Columbus upon his arrival on Hispañola in 1492. Words from their language were adapted into the English words "tobacco" and "barbecue".
A 1518 epidemic of this "Old World" disease was responsible for the deaths of 90% of the Taíno population. Edward Jenner developed a vaccine for this disease.
Areytos were often composed to honor these Taíno deities, who were often represented as stone or wooden idols. One of them who governed storms, named Juracán, lends his name to the word "hurricane".

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, name these authors who contributed to developing the notion of the "Great American Novel" in the 19th century:
answers_sanitized: Henry James [prompt on James] (The novel is Washington Square.)
parts: Many critics cite a novel about a raft trip down the Mississippi by this author from Hannibal, Missouri as the first Great American Novel.

This author introduced the abbreviation "GAN" for the Great American Novel. A park in Manhattan titles this author's novel about the heiress Catherine Sloper, who eventually rejects the gold-digging Morris Townsend.
This author of the Civil War novel Miss Ravenel's Conversion from Secession to Loyalty coined the term "Great American Novel" in an essay for The Nation magazine.

bonuses.leadin: Different parts of Jesus' body are honored by the seven pieces of this composer's cantata cycle Membra Jesu Nostri ("MEM-brah YEH-soo NOHS-tree"). For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: passacaglia ("pah-suh-KAHL-yuh") [accept Passacaglia and Fugue in C minor]
parts: Name this composer of dozens of chorale ("koh-RAHL") preludes which heavily influenced those of J.S. Bach. His only works published in his lifetime were two sets of 7 trio sonatas.
Buxtehude's preludes and dozens of his other pieces were written for this loud keyboard instrument, as was Bach's Toccata and Fugue in D minor, which appears in Fantasia.
Buxtehude wrote a D minor organ piece in this form in 3/2 time. A C minor Bach organ piece pairs a section in this form with a fugue and consists of 20 variations on a ground bass ostinato.

bonuses.leadin: A widely-cited 1999 Nature paper published 420,000 years of atmospheric gas data based on some of these samples, whose isotopic content is used to model past global temperatures. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify these samples which scientists at Vostok and McMurdo stations obtain via drilling.
Excavating ice cores is one of our sources on the history of this landmass, which contains the world's largest polar desert.

Findings of this substance in ice cores indicate that Antarctica was home to large forests about 15 to 20 million years ago. This "epicuticular" substance consists of a mixture of n-alkanes, making it strongly hydrophobic.

bonuses.leadin: In Men and Citizens, Judith Shklar suggests that the utopian "happy family" portrayed in this novel contradicts its author's utopian vision of a republic. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: atheists [or atheism] (Wolmar is a portrayal of the Baron d'Holbach.)
parts: Name this epistolary novel whose title character is a "New Héloïse" who is taught by Saint-Preux ("sont-proo").
Julie is by this French philosopher and author who described an ideal education in the novel Emile ("eh-MEEL").

In Julie, Rousseau portrays one of his French-German philosopher contemporaries as Wolmar, a "virtuous" example of these people. The Savoyard Vicar from Emile has the "manners of a beggar" and principles of one of these people, and "affects to be" one to be a contrarian.

bonuses.leadin: A folk etymology claims this king is the namesake of part of the Scottish Lowlands along the southern banks of the Firth of Forth. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: King Lot [or Loth; or Lothus; or Leudonus; or Lewdwn; or Llewdwn Lluydauc; prompt on Lleu; prompt on Lothian, Laudonia, Leudonia, Lodonesia, Lowden, Loudan, or Lodainn]
Sir Gawain [or Gauwaine; or Gwalchmei ap Gwyar; or Walwen; or Gualguanus; or Waluanus; or Gauvain; accept Sir Gawain and the Green Knight]
Geoffrey of Monmouth [or Galfridus Monemutensis, or Galfridus Arturus, or Galfridus Artur, or Gruffudd ap Arthur, or Sieffre o Fynwy]
parts: Name this legendary king of the Picts who, in the post-Vulgate Cycle, is slain by King Pellinore, resulting in a blood feud between the two men's families.
The feud against Pellinore is carried on by this son of Lot, a Knight of the Round Table. In another story, this man fights the Green Knight.

The History of the Kings of Britain written by this clergyman from Monmouth ("MAWN-muth") elevates Lot to a more prominent role than earlier tales, making him a close ally of Arthur and heir to the throne of Norway.

bonuses.leadin: Common experimental designs in this field include "go/no go" and "forced choice" tasks. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: psychophysics [or perceptual physics; prompt on psychometrics]
just-noticeable difference [or JND; prompt on noticeable difference]
parts: Name this field pioneered by Gustav Fechner which quantitatively investigates the relationships between stimuli and resulting sensations.
Psychophysics often searches for this value, defined as a change in stimulus which a subject detects 50 percent of the time. Weber's law suggests it is directly proportional to the original stimulus.

Practitioners of this area of business may use psychophysics to see if segments of consumers notice a difference when product attributes change. Strategies in this field may be "D2C" or "B2B" focused.

bonuses.leadin: This philosopher's use of "spillover-goblet words" is often compared to Plato's notion of "leaky pots". For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Zhuangzi ("zhwang-zuh") [or Zhuang Zhou, or Chuang Tzu, or Master Zhuang; prompt on Zhuang]
transmigration of souls [or metempsychosis; prompt on transmigration or reincarnation or rebirth]
parts: Name this 3rd century B.C. philosopher whose namesake text contains the story of "Drumming on a Tub and Singing" and provides the most thorough exposition of an earlier man's doctrine of wu wei.

Herbert Giles used the Greek name for this process to describe Zhuangzi's dream of entering the body of a butterfly. In the Meno, Socrates explains recollection with the analogy of a tale in which this process is caused by Persephone.

The notion of de ("duh"), as treated in the Zhuangzi, is often translated into English as this concept. Plato and Aristotle put forth an ethics based on this concept, which is often contrasted with vice.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about director Frank Capra's involvement in World War II:
answers_sanitized: Dr. Seuss [or Theodore Seuss Geisel; accept Dr. Seuss Goes to War]
parts: Capra came up with the idea of a cartoon character of this lowest military rank named SNAFU for a series of Looney Tunes instructional videos for soldiers.
Capra directed this series of seven propaganda films, beginning with Prelude to War, which explain the goals of US involvement in the war.

This person wrote the script of Capra's film Your Job in Germany, which depicts World War II as a racial conflict against the "eternal German". Richard Minear's book titled "[this person] goes to War" includes 200 of this person's World War II cartoons.

bonuses.leadin: These devices are often equipped with UARTs to facilitate conversion between parallel and serial data. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these programmable integrated circuits, which consist of a CPU, memory, and multiple I/O ports. Arduino packages the AVR variety of these devices onto single printed circuit boards.
Many Arduino ICs have an SCL line, which serves this purpose in the I²C ("EYE-two-SEE") protocol for communication. These devices' namesake "cycles", measured in hertz, rate the speed of a CPU.
This quantity is the speed at which serially-communicated data is transferred. The Arduino code "Serial.begin()" (serial-DOT-begin) sets this value when reading analog signals.
